slides.title: The Haber Process
slides.content:
# The Haber Process âš—ï¸

Producing ammonia (NHâ‚ƒ) from nitrogen and hydrogen.

## The Reaction

```
Nâ‚‚(g) + 3Hâ‚‚(g) â‡Œ 2NHâ‚ƒ(g)    Î”H = -92 kJ/mol
```

## Conditions

| Factor | Condition | Why? |
|--------|-----------|------|
| Temperature | 400-500Â°C | Speed vs. equilibrium |
| Pressure | 150-300 atm | Shifts right (fewer moles) |
| Catalyst | Iron (Fe) | Speeds up both directions |

## Le Chatelier Analysis

### Pressure
- High pressure favors products (4 mol â†’ 2 mol)
- Limited by cost and safety

### Temperature
- Low temperature favors products (exothermic)
- BUT: Reaction too slow at low T
- **Compromise:** 400-500Â°C

## The Compromise

```
    Want: High yield (low T, high P)
    Need: Fast rate (high T, catalyst)
    
    Solution: Medium T + catalyst + high P
    
    Yield: ~15% per pass
    BUT: Recycle unreacted gases!
```

## Importance

- 80% of ammonia â†’ Fertilizers
- Also: Explosives, plastics, cleaning products
- Supports ~50% of world food production

## Fritz Haber

- Developed process 1909
- Nobel Prize 1918
- Controversial figure (chemical weapons in WWI)

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** The Haber process is perhaps the most important industrial reaction ever developed!

## Key Terminology

| Term | Definition |
|------|------------|
| Electrolyte | Ionic compound (molten or dissolved) |

## Electrolysis of Water

```

```

Volume ratio: Hâ‚‚ : Oâ‚‚ = 2 : 1

## Industrial Electrolysis

### Aluminum Production (Hall-HÃ©roult)

```
2Alâ‚‚Oâ‚ƒ â†’ 4Al + 3Oâ‚‚
```

### Chlor-Alkali Process


slides.title: Contact Process & Sulfuric Acid
slides.content:
# Contact Process ðŸ§ª

Producing sulfuric acid - the most produced chemical!

## Why Sulfuric Acid?

> "A nation's industrial development can be measured by its Hâ‚‚SOâ‚„ production."

| Use | % of production |
|-----|----------------|
| Fertilizers (phosphates) | 60% |
| Chemical manufacturing | 20% |
| Metal processing | 10% |
| Other | 10% |

## The Process

### Step 1: Burning Sulfur
```
S + Oâ‚‚ â†’ SOâ‚‚
```

### Step 2: Oxidation (Contact step)
```
2SOâ‚‚ + Oâ‚‚ â‡Œ 2SOâ‚ƒ    Î”H = -196 kJ/mol
```

Conditions:
- Temperature: 400-450Â°C
- Pressure: 1-2 atm
- Catalyst: Vâ‚‚Oâ‚… (vanadium pentoxide)

### Step 3: Absorption
```
SOâ‚ƒ + Hâ‚‚SOâ‚„ â†’ Hâ‚‚Sâ‚‚Oâ‚‡ (oleum)
Hâ‚‚Sâ‚‚Oâ‚‡ + Hâ‚‚O â†’ 2Hâ‚‚SOâ‚„
```

(Not directly: SOâ‚ƒ + Hâ‚‚O creates dangerous acid mist)

## Similar to Haber Process

| Factor | Haber | Contact |
|--------|-------|--------|
| Exothermic? | Yes | Yes |
| Catalyst | Fe | Vâ‚‚Oâ‚… |
| Compromise T? | Yes | Yes |
| High pressure? | Yes | No (already high yield) |

## Environmental Concern

- SOâ‚‚ emissions cause acid rain
- Modern plants capture 99.5%+ of SOâ‚‚

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Sulfuric acid is used to make almost everything else!

# Soaps and Detergents ðŸ§¼

## How Cleaning Works

Dirt is often oily/greasy â€“ water alone can't remove it.

## Surfactants

Molecules with:
- **Hydrophilic head** - Loves water
- **Hydrophobic tail** - Loves oil/grease

```
    Hydrophobic        Hydrophilic
       tail               head
    ~~~~~~~~~~            O
                          â”‚
    Non-polar           Polar
```

## How It Works

```
1. Surfactant surrounds grease droplet
2. Tails insert into grease
3. Heads face water
4. Forms micelle
5. Grease washes away!

           Water
         â†—  â†‘  â†–
    â—‹â”€â”€~~/  â”‚  \~~â—‹
   Head â—  GREASE  â— Tail in grease
    â—‹â”€â”€~~\  â”‚  /~~â—‹
         â†˜  â†“  â†™
           Water
```

## Soap vs Detergent

| Property | Soap | Detergent |
|----------|------|-----------|
| Made from | Natural fats + NaOH | Synthetic |
| In hard water | Forms scum | Works well |
| Biodegradable | Yes | Some yes, some no |
| Cost | Higher | Lower |

## Soap Making (Saponification)

```
Fat + NaOH â†’ Soap + Glycerol
```

## Hard Water Problem

```
2RCOONa + CaÂ²âº â†’ (RCOO)â‚‚Caâ†“ + 2Naâº
  Soap            Insoluble scum
```

Detergents don't have this problem!

## Ingredients in Products

| Ingredient | Purpose |
|------------|--------|
| Surfactants | Cleaning |
| Builders | Soften water |
| Bleaches | Remove stains |
| Enzymes | Break down proteins |
| Fragrances | Pleasant smell |

> ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Look for biodegradable detergents to protect waterways!

slides.title: Nanotechnology
slides.content:
# Nanotechnology ðŸ”¬

## What is Nanotechnology?

Manipulating matter at the nanometer scale (1-100 nm).

```
1 nm = 10â»â¹ m = one-billionth of a meter

For scale:
- Human hair: 80,000 nm wide
- DNA: 2 nm wide
- Atom: 0.1-0.5 nm
```

## Why Nano is Special

| Property | Changes at nanoscale |
|----------|---------------------|
| Surface area | Massively increased |
| Optical | Color changes (gold: red) |
| Electrical | Quantum effects |
| Mechanical | Stronger per weight |
| Chemical | More reactive |

## Nanomaterials

### Carbon Nanotubes
- Rolled graphene sheets
- Strongest material known
- Excellent electrical conductivity

### Graphene
- Single layer of carbon atoms
- 200Ã— stronger than steel
- Nobel Prize 2010

### Quantum Dots
- Semiconductor nanoparticles
- Size determines color
- Used in displays

### Nanoparticles
- Silver: Antimicrobial
- Gold: Medical imaging
- TiOâ‚‚: Sunscreen, self-cleaning

## Applications

| Field | Application |
|-------|------------|
| Medicine | Drug delivery, imaging |
| Electronics | Smaller, faster chips |
| Energy | Better solar cells, batteries |
| Materials | Stronger, lighter composites |
| Environment | Water purification |

## Concerns

- Unknown health effects
- Environmental fate
- Regulation challenges

> ðŸ’¡ **Future:** Nanotechnology may revolutionize medicine, computing, and materials!

slides.title: Materials Science
slides.content:
# Materials Science ðŸ”©

## Types of Materials

| Type | Examples | Properties |
|------|----------|------------|
| Metals | Iron, aluminum, copper | Conductive, ductile |
| Ceramics | Glass, porcelain, concrete | Hard, brittle |
| Polymers | Plastics, rubber | Flexible, moldable |
| Composites | Fiberglass, carbon fiber | Combined properties |

## Alloys

Mixture of metals (or metal + non-metal).

| Alloy | Composition | Use |
|-------|-------------|-----|
| Steel | Fe + C | Construction |
| Bronze | Cu + Sn | Bearings |
| Brass | Cu + Zn | Fittings |
| Stainless steel | Fe + Cr + Ni | Cutlery |

### Why Alloys?
- Stronger than pure metals
- Different layers slide less easily
- Tailored properties

## Smart Materials

| Material | Property | Application |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| Shape memory alloys | Return to original shape | Stents, glasses frames |
| Piezoelectric | Electricity â†” pressure | Sensors, speakers |
| Photochromic | Darken in light | Sunglasses |
| Thermochromic | Color changes with temperature | Thermometers |

## Composites

```
    Matrix (continuous)  +  Reinforcement
    (e.g., plastic)        (e.g., carbon fiber)
                â†“
         Composite
    (stronger than either alone)
```

### Examples
- Carbon fiber reinforced plastic (CFRP)
- Fiberglass
- Reinforced concrete

## Selection Criteria

- Mechanical properties
- Thermal properties
- Cost
- Weight
- Environmental impact
- Availability

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Insight:** Materials science is where chemistry meets engineering!
